docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna, the health insurer, said yesterday that first-quarter profit rose 11 percent as the company added more than 300,000 customers. Net income rose to $365.8 million, or $2.28 a share, from $330 million, or $2.12, a year earlier, the company, based in Hartford, said. For the first time since 1999, Aetna is signing up more members as competitors are turning to acquisitions to fuel growth. Aetna said profit was $1.75 a share excluding adjustments to reserves, capital gains and completion of tax audits for discontinued operations. On that basis, the company was expected to earn $1.72 a share, the average estimate of 20 analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Shares of the company fell $4.03, or 4.5 percent, to $83.72 yesterday. They had risen 30 percent this year.

headline.main: AETNA SAYS PROFIT ROSE 11%, AIDED BY NEW CUSTOMERS

docs.abstract: Aetna says first-quarter profit rose 11 percent; net income rose to $365.8 million from $330 million year earlier (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The American economy grew at a vigorous annual rate of 4.2 percent in the first quarter, with military spending making a significant contribution to economic growth for the first time since the early days of the war in Iraq. Consumers provided most of the lift, the Bureau of Economic Analysis reported yesterday. Business investment was also strong, adding more to the growth rate than the military outlays. Without the war spending, however, the gross domestic product would have expanded at an only mediocre pace: 3.5 percent.

headline.main: U.S. Economy Grows 4.2%; War Spending Provides Push

docs.abstract: Bureau of Economic Analysis reports economy grew at vigorous annual rate of 4.2 percent in first quarter, with military spending making significant contribution to economic growth for first time since early days of war in Iraq; gross domestic product would have expanded at 3.5 percent pace without war; Bush administration greets report as confirmation that tax cuts are working; Treas Sec John W Snow says economy is poised for long-term growth; Sen John Kerry, presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, focuses not on Gross Domestic Product report but on still subpar job creation; neither party addresses unexpected contribution of military spending to economic growth, which accounted for $17.4 billion of $108.5 billion increase; inflation rose at annual rate of 2 percent, up from 1.2 percent in fourth quarter; Labor Department reports employment cost index rose at 1.1 percent annual rate because employers' health insurance and pension costs increased; graph; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The government on Thursday activated a Web site documenting wide variation in prices for scores of prescription drugs at thousands of pharmacies around the country. In many cases, the prices offered to Medicare beneficiaries, with the help of new drug discount cards, appear similar to the prices available to any consumer using online pharmacies.

headline.main: Web Site Shows Variation in Drug Prices

docs.abstract: Medicare activates Web site that documents wide variation in prices for scores of prescription drugs at thousands of pharmacies across country; many of prices offered to Medicare beneficiaries with new discount cards appear similar to what any consumer can obtain online; examples cited (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Proposal to Hand Over Falluja Task to Iraqi Force United States military officials in Falluja moved to halt their siege of the city, proposing to turn over the task of ending the anti-American insurgency to a new force of Iraqi soldiers, led by officers once loyal to Saddam Hussein. Pentagon officials said the plan was one of a number of possible solutions under discussion. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Medicare plans today to open a Web site designed to help millions of older Americans compare prices of their prescription drugs. The site is the first big-league test for DestinationRx, a little-known company that Medicare hired without competitive bidding to design and run the system. If it works as advertised, Medicare enrollees will be able to visit the site to find prices of their particular medications at nearby stores that will accept Medicare-certified discount cards. They could then use the information to decide which card would help them most when the discount program starts on June 1.

headline.main: Medicare and Little-Known Company Open Site to Compare Drug Prices
